PROSPECTS BRIGHT
FOR SWIMMING TEAM
Warlow Will Act as Manager
for Jay Natators
HAMBLETON IS COACH
Practice To Be Held in The
K. of C. Pool Twice a Week
The swimming squad, for a long
time a defunct branch of athletics
at Hopkins, has been revived in the
Past two years by the acumen and
perseverance of Coach Hambleton
and Karl Flocks, the latter of whom
Was lost through gi-aduation. But in
last year's election Francis Warlow,
the president of the Student Council, was elected to manage the trials
and tribulations of the J. H. U. dolphins.
Warlow has exhibited his capability in swimming and it is quite
evident that as manager,he does not
fall short of the reputation he has
hitherto enjoyed. He has prepared
a schedule of almost ten meets, of
Which out-of-town sessions are preeminent. The usual matches with
Delaware, Gettysburg, - George
Washington and Catholic University promise to have happy results.
menace in the schedule, however,
is the coming tussle with New York
University at Manhattan. This
will be the first evidence of a Northern trip by the swimMing squad, as
heretofore meets have been held
only within a radius of seventy-five
miles from Baltimore. Hopkins, by
thus extending her reputation, may
he able to meet more of the New
England colleges in future years.
Lettermen Return

Both Warlow and Mr. Hambleton
consider the prospects, on the whole,
very bright. Almost all the winners
of the swimming letter have returned this year to gather new
laurels for Hopkins. The famed
"EFGH" relay team—composed of
Edmund, Frey, Gordon and Hanhart—is intact with the exception of
Edmund, who was graduated last
June. However, even this phase of
the tank will be changed by the new
rules adopted by the Intercollegiate
Swimming Association,_
Unlike the relay of the past,
where each of the three men swam
free-style two lengths of a regulation twenty-five yard pool, the new
System involves a threefold change.
This event has been christened the
medley relay" and considering the
nature of it, this is an appropriate
title. There are only three men who
respectively swim the !free style,
breaststroke and backstroke. This
Will be to Hopkins, as well as other
colleges swimming under the dictates of the I. S. A. and the Amateur Athletic Union, a complete innovation.
Rumor Not Confirmed

The rumor that the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association is financing the team this year has not been
Officially confirmed. It is well to
remember that until the season of
1929-30, the swimming squad was
Operated as a club, not even being
recognized by that body as a minor
sport. However, last year the association, after a bitter fight, sponsored the team and permitted it to
he called the Johns Hopkins Swimming Squad. But sponsoring was
not sufficient. The expenses were
tremendous and were borne by each
member of the squad. The team was
merely operating in its wonted manner, and the only redeeming feature
of the recognition
was that the association presented a certificate with
the swimming letter, thus making
the.letter official. This
year the team
desires more. They wish to be dependent upon the Athletic Associati°n, financially, just as the tennis or

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 28, 1930
R. N. Dempster Issues
Ultimatum to Students

It has just been announced
by the registrar, Mr. R. N.
Dempster, that all freshmen
and sophomores who have not
taken their physical examinations by November 1, will be
fined. This ruling also applies to all seniors and juniors
who are members of the R.
0. T. C. The amount of- the
fine has not as yet been decided.
This is the first time in the
University's history that such
an action has been taken. The
reason for this step is that
students have been unusually
lax in reporting to Dr. Abercrombie.
Examinations are held daily,
except Fridays, in the north
loft of Gilman Hall, from 3
to 5.

Avukah Believes Britain
Has Repudiated Balfour
Last Friday, the first meeting of
the Avukah Society, which is affiliated with the student Zionist Federation of America, was held at 1
o'clock, in 117 Gilman. Hall.
The topic which was chosen for
discussion was the Simpson Report,
and its effect on Judaism. The discussion waxed furiously concerning
its effects, economically, politically,
and morally upon Jewish aspirations for a National Homeland.
Particular emphasis, due to the
present economic depression, was
placed on the clause restricting immigration of Jews into Palestine as
long as there is Arabian unemployment.
The unanimous opinion of the
group taking part in the above discussion was that the avowed policy
of Great Britain toward Zionism, as
expressed in the Balfour Declaration (a determination to create a
Jewish Homeland in Palestine) has

Advent ofAutumn Evidenced by Dearth Of Lang
Hoppers, Bridge Assiduity, and Red ./‘'oses
Fall has come to the Hopkins
campus! Lo and behold! The
grasshoppers that once chirped gaily
in the stretch of grass between Gilman and Remsen and the Physics
Building have departed for unknown shores. The Chemistry and
Physics Laboratories are full not
only of rancorous odors but also of
frost-bitten youths who prefer to
undergo the balmy yet pungent atmosphere of Remsen rather than the
healthful yet frigid climate of the
outdoors. Topcoats adorn the backs
of chairs in Levering, the boys are
playing bridge with more gesticulations, the ehess players sacrifice prudence for celerity and the general
impression an old timer gets is one
of a pace not exactly quickened by
the normal dictates of civilization.
The weather, often merely a
space-filler in puerile letters to
mama, again looms up as an important element of our daily lives.
The trees are instilled with new
hues, their feathery tennants have
left for new lands. Only the more
stalwart of the birds have remained.
The clucking timid hens that adorn
the portals of Levering Hall as the
sanctified ibis once did for the
Egyptians, will not be destroyed by
the elements—no, they are far too
hardy for such an ignominous finish. Eventually they will take on
the Egyptian tinge that they lack in
the life and in death they can be
recognized in the brown pyramids
described by the, culinary department of Leveling Hall as "Chicken
croquettes", 25c.
At the entrance to the Mechanical
Engineering Building we see myriads of gloved hands awkwardly
adjusted delicate instruments, on
tripods. The owners of these hands
are not photographers but members
of a class in surveying. Their cardinal asset is not their ability to tell
you how far that Austen is from the
Cord, but their apparent immunity

Donors lo Attend Annual
Chemical Conference Nov. 7
Leadership Addresses to be Given by Dr. Little; Sound Film of
Millikan's Talk "Cosmic Rays," to be
Open to Public
The second annual conference of
donors to the Johns Hopkins National Chemical Education Fellowship Plan will be held at Homewood,
November 7. Among those present
will be donors, faculty members,
and invited guests.
To Be Welcomed by President

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
Johns Hopkins, will welcome the
convening group in Remsen Hall,
114, at 10 A. M. At the conclusion
of Dr. Ames' welcome, at 10.30
A. M., the donors and faculty will
meet in the Chemistry Library,
Remsen Hall, to discuss the conditions for the annual renewal of fellowships. At this time, C. G. Campbell, president, Kewaunee Manufacturing Company, and Dr. H. A. B.
Dunning, of Hynson, Westcdtt,
Dunning will be leaders in the discussion. Beginning at 2 P. M., in
Levering Hall, a conference on the
selection, education, and testing of
students who possess creative ability
in the chemical field will be held.
Leaders for these discussions are to
be Martin Matheson, director of
John Wiley and Sons, Inc.; J. C.
W. Frazer, chairman, J. H. U. Department of Chemistry; A. A. Backhaus, vice-president, U. S. Industrial Alcohol Company, and F. A.
Clements, director of research, General Motors Corporation.

luncheon will be served in Levering

a dinner to be given at the Baltimore Country Club, 6 P. M.
To Present Address, Film

The conference will be culminated by an address, "Leadership,"
scheduled to be delivered at 8 P. M.,
by Dr. Arthur D. Little, noted
chemical engineer, in the C. E. Hall,
Room 120. In addition, the sound
picture "Cosmic Rays," a speech
presented at the first conference in
1929 by Dr. Robert A. Millikan,
famous physicist, will be shown.
Only those who have obtained complimentary tickets from the office of
Dr. Neil E. Gordon, Remsen 105,
will have reserved seats for the final
address, open to the public.
Hundreds Turned Away

When Dr. Milikan made his
public appearance at Johns Hopkins, April 24, 1929, hundreds were
unable to hear his address. As a
consequence, it was explained by
Dr. Gordon the sound film reproduction of the address was made. It

benefit of especially those who had
failed to hear him previously.

The orange paint has done immense

crises; and a plan for the complete
reorganization of labor.

machine which supports all the reactionary measures of the government against the laborers."

the workers are beginning to realize

made. He called attention to the

PASSES PUT TURNBULL
IN SCORING POSITION
Two Lyons To Bauer Forwards
Place Hopkins On 6-Yard
Line
A blocked attempt to score an extra point after touchdown proved
to be the deciding factor in a close
game at Swarthmore and Hopkins
finished on the long end of a 7-6
score last Saturday. Lang, a freshman end, blocked Dellmuth's attempt for the extra point after
Schemb had scored ill the final
quarter.
Against Lehigh, two weeks ago,
the Jays met a team with more experience and were defeated. Against
Rutgers last week the Black and
Blue gridders were outweighed and
the process was repeated. But Saturday the Hopkins team was pitted
against an eleven of ,equal caliber
and the result was a victory by the
margin of a lone point. The victory
was not overwhelming but it was
the result of a hard-fought, bitterly
contested battle.
First Period Scoreless

With two equally strong teams
trying each other out the first period
was scoreless. Each team made
gains but neither was able to cross
the other's goal line. Swarthmore
had an opportunity to score late in
this period when Schemb punted to
Lyons and the latter fumbled.
Keefer, Garnet guard, recovered the
ball in Hopkins' territory and the
Pennsylvanians were in a position
to score. However,- a stubborn Jay
line held for three downs and then
Dellmuth attempted a field goal. As
a forewarning of what was to come,
lang blocked the placement kick and
the quarter ended before the home
team was again in-. a scoring position.
Passes Advanced Hopkins

With the beginning of the second
quarter the Jays' attack began to
function. A long pass from Lyons
to Bauer placed the ball deep in the
Garnet territory. --Another long
pass completed by the game two men
left Hopkins in Possession of the
ball on Swarthmore's six-yard line.
Turnbull got four..through the center of the line and on the next play
went across for the 'first score of
the game. Bauer added the extra
point with a placement kick that
went between the crossbars. There
was no more scoring during the
quarter and the half -ended with
Hopkins seven points._ in the lead.
Swarthmore .seemed determined
to at least tie the score in the second
half and all during the third quarter threatened the Jay goal. However, the Black and 'Blue team stiffened whenever danger seemed imminent and the third period passed
without a score.
Lang Blocks Kick

In the middle of the last quarter
Lyons punted while in the shadow
of his goal posts. The ball went to
Schemb on the Hopkins' 40-yard
line. Cutting through the entire Jay
team when it seemed certain that he
would be stopped the:•Garnet fullback back scored. 'It' was then that
Lang again broke up: Delln-iuth's attempted kick and, victory. for the
visitors was assured. . Neither. team
could score during the,remainder of
the contest.

EDITORIALS
CRITICISM
is a power very much abused at johns Hopkins, both
CRITICISM
by the critics and the criticised. The former, finding this enticing
weapon so readily within his grasp, is often carried away by his more
or less venomous attitude and rather than being coldly critical and
constructive be becomqs vulgarly insulting—a condition vividly illustrated in this university in several notorious cases. This unfortunate
tendency, with some exceptions, seems due to a fervent desire to rise
beyond the bounds of the conventional and commonplace to the plane
of originality. It is a laudable craving, no one is more uninteresting
or exasperating than the confirmed, self-satisfied Victorian. Yet
original criticism must also be intelligent and not have to include disparagement and insult to command the attention. It must be in good
taste and good taste does not look to conventionalism for its limits.
It is only to the conventional and narrowminded themselves that it
ever does o. However, good taste and intelligence to a great extent
do walk hand in hand and if the critic would desire to cater to the
intelligensia he should also cater to this sense of good taste.
The criticised we find are affected by criticisms in two ways. On
the one hand we find smug indifference and on the other garrulous
savageness. In truth, both are but different attitudes occasioned by
the same fundamental fault; that is, utter disregard of any intelligent
opinions which the critic may, with a serious desire at improvement,
have advanced. This fault may not be so clear in the overferocious
as in the indifferent. The former seldom considers the critic's arguments as an attempt at helpfulness, which sometimes it is, but rather
as a vengeful assault upon his personal honor. He enters the fray
much in the same attitude as the aforementioned critic and childish
epistles fly back and forth in puerile enmity. It is a question which is
the worse evil. In neither case is the critic given the answer which
the merits of his observations deserve.
THE NEWS-LETTER is the only organ of University opinion and,
as such, it is its policy to print whatever matter it can of this kind that
is responsibly submitted to it. It seems that in an intellectual institution like the Johns Hopkins University intelligent criticisms should
appear, be accepted and answered as such, no matter to what member
or department of the institution, student, faculty, or administrative it
may be addressed. We hope that in the future we will receive just
criticisms and that these criticisms be given the importance they
deserve.

BIOLOGY I
on the subject of criticisms we are reminded of one that
WHILE
has oftentimes been brought, usually humorously, however, to
our attention. That is, the untrustworthiness of the college catalogues.
We would like to point to a specific case.
Three lecture classes and two laboratory periods have been prescribed as the required hours for Biology I. However, upon enquiring
from several students we find that the biology department assigns so
much laboratory work that it is impossible for the students to complete
the material unless the equivalent of at least three afternoons are spent
in the laboratory each week. This procedure is not only unfair to the
students, who receive no credit for the compulsory time spent, but
also to the other departments of the University, who must suffer when
the students discover this unforeseen drain on their time. If the biology
department requires more than two afternoons a week in which to
present its course, then official recognition should be made of the fact
and due credit given.

A. F. of L. Backs Capitalists

-In the meanwhile, what is the
organized labor, the A. F. of L.,
doing to alleviate this condition of
unemployment that is so evident?"
Mr. Gitlow explained that it could
do nothing. "As long as industry
is run for profit, and not to supply
the needs of man, suffering will
occur." He showed that the only
solution to the problem was either
to supply work to the laborers, or to
protect them by social insurance of
some kind. The former alternative
is evidently impossible under the
capitalistic system and the A. F. of
L. has shown itself to be definitely
opposed to insurance, backing the
stand of the capitalists.
"The crying need of the worker,"

labor union with a gvo4-1 program,

PROSPECTS BRIGHT
FOR SWIMMING TEAM
Warlow Will Act as Manager
for Jay Natators
HAMBLETON IS COACH
Practice To Be Held in The
K. of C. Pool Twice a Week
The swimming squad, for a long
time a defunct branch of athletics
at Hopkins, has been revived in the
Past two years by the acumen and
perseverance of Coach Hambleton
and Karl Flocks, the latter of whom
Was lost through gi-aduation. But in
last year's election Francis Warlow,
the president of the Student Council, was elected to manage the trials
and tribulations of the J. H. U. dolphins.
Warlow has exhibited his capability in swimming and it is quite
evident that as manager,he does not
fall short of the reputation he has
hitherto enjoyed. He has prepared
a schedule of almost ten meets, of
Which out-of-town sessions are preeminent. The usual matches with
Delaware, Gettysburg, - George
Washington and Catholic University promise to have happy results.
menace in the schedule, however,
is the coming tussle with New York
University at Manhattan. This
will be the first evidence of a Northern trip by the swimMing squad, as
heretofore meets have been held
only within a radius of seventy-five
miles from Baltimore. Hopkins, by
thus extending her reputation, may
he able to meet more of the New
England colleges in future years.
Lettermen Return

Both Warlow and Mr. Hambleton
consider the prospects, on the whole,
very bright. Almost all the winners
of the swimming letter have returned this year to gather new
laurels for Hopkins. The famed
"EFGH" relay team—composed of
Edmund, Frey, Gordon and Hanhart—is intact with the exception of
Edmund, who was graduated last
June. However, even this phase of
the tank will be changed by the new
rules adopted by the Intercollegiate
Swimming Association,_
Unlike the relay of the past,
where each of the three men swam
free-style two lengths of a regulation twenty-five yard pool, the new
System involves a threefold change.
This event has been christened the
medley relay" and considering the
nature of it, this is an appropriate
title. There are only three men who
respectively swim the !free style,
breaststroke and backstroke. This
Will be to Hopkins, as well as other
colleges swimming under the dictates of the I. S. A. and the Amateur Athletic Union, a complete innovation.
Rumor Not Confirmed

The rumor that the Johns Hopkins Athletic Association is financing the team this year has not been
Officially confirmed. It is well to
remember that until the season of
1929-30, the swimming squad was
Operated as a club, not even being
recognized by that body as a minor
sport. However, last year the association, after a bitter fight, sponsored the team and permitted it to
he called the Johns Hopkins Swimming Squad. But sponsoring was
not sufficient. The expenses were
tremendous and were borne by each
member of the squad. The team was
merely operating in its wonted manner, and the only redeeming feature
of the recognition
was that the association presented a certificate with
the swimming letter, thus making
the.letter official. This
year the team
desires more. They wish to be dependent upon the Athletic Associati°n, financially, just as the tennis or

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 28, 1930
R. N. Dempster Issues
Ultimatum to Students

It has just been announced
by the registrar, Mr. R. N.
Dempster, that all freshmen
and sophomores who have not
taken their physical examinations by November 1, will be
fined. This ruling also applies to all seniors and juniors
who are members of the R.
0. T. C. The amount of- the
fine has not as yet been decided.
This is the first time in the
University's history that such
an action has been taken. The
reason for this step is that
students have been unusually
lax in reporting to Dr. Abercrombie.
Examinations are held daily,
except Fridays, in the north
loft of Gilman Hall, from 3
to 5.

Avukah Believes Britain
Has Repudiated Balfour
Last Friday, the first meeting of
the Avukah Society, which is affiliated with the student Zionist Federation of America, was held at 1
o'clock, in 117 Gilman. Hall.
The topic which was chosen for
discussion was the Simpson Report,
and its effect on Judaism. The discussion waxed furiously concerning
its effects, economically, politically,
and morally upon Jewish aspirations for a National Homeland.
Particular emphasis, due to the
present economic depression, was
placed on the clause restricting immigration of Jews into Palestine as
long as there is Arabian unemployment.
The unanimous opinion of the
group taking part in the above discussion was that the avowed policy
of Great Britain toward Zionism, as
expressed in the Balfour Declaration (a determination to create a
Jewish Homeland in Palestine) has

Advent ofAutumn Evidenced by Dearth Of Lang
Hoppers, Bridge Assiduity, and Red ./‘'oses
Fall has come to the Hopkins
campus! Lo and behold! The
grasshoppers that once chirped gaily
in the stretch of grass between Gilman and Remsen and the Physics
Building have departed for unknown shores. The Chemistry and
Physics Laboratories are full not
only of rancorous odors but also of
frost-bitten youths who prefer to
undergo the balmy yet pungent atmosphere of Remsen rather than the
healthful yet frigid climate of the
outdoors. Topcoats adorn the backs
of chairs in Levering, the boys are
playing bridge with more gesticulations, the ehess players sacrifice prudence for celerity and the general
impression an old timer gets is one
of a pace not exactly quickened by
the normal dictates of civilization.
The weather, often merely a
space-filler in puerile letters to
mama, again looms up as an important element of our daily lives.
The trees are instilled with new
hues, their feathery tennants have
left for new lands. Only the more
stalwart of the birds have remained.
The clucking timid hens that adorn
the portals of Levering Hall as the
sanctified ibis once did for the
Egyptians, will not be destroyed by
the elements—no, they are far too
hardy for such an ignominous finish. Eventually they will take on
the Egyptian tinge that they lack in
the life and in death they can be
recognized in the brown pyramids
described by the, culinary department of Leveling Hall as "Chicken
croquettes", 25c.
At the entrance to the Mechanical
Engineering Building we see myriads of gloved hands awkwardly
adjusted delicate instruments, on
tripods. The owners of these hands
are not photographers but members
of a class in surveying. Their cardinal asset is not their ability to tell
you how far that Austen is from the
Cord, but their apparent immunity

Donors lo Attend Annual
Chemical Conference Nov. 7
Leadership Addresses to be Given by Dr. Little; Sound Film of
Millikan's Talk "Cosmic Rays," to be
Open to Public
The second annual conference of
donors to the Johns Hopkins National Chemical Education Fellowship Plan will be held at Homewood,
November 7. Among those present
will be donors, faculty members,
and invited guests.
To Be Welcomed by President

Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of
Johns Hopkins, will welcome the
convening group in Remsen Hall,
114, at 10 A. M. At the conclusion
of Dr. Ames' welcome, at 10.30
A. M., the donors and faculty will
meet in the Chemistry Library,
Remsen Hall, to discuss the conditions for the annual renewal of fellowships. At this time, C. G. Campbell, president, Kewaunee Manufacturing Company, and Dr. H. A. B.
Dunning, of Hynson, Westcdtt,
Dunning will be leaders in the discussion. Beginning at 2 P. M., in
Levering Hall, a conference on the
selection, education, and testing of
students who possess creative ability
in the chemical field will be held.
Leaders for these discussions are to
be Martin Matheson, director of
John Wiley and Sons, Inc.; J. C.
W. Frazer, chairman, J. H. U. Department of Chemistry; A. A. Backhaus, vice-president, U. S. Industrial Alcohol Company, and F. A.
Clements, director of research, General Motors Corporation.

Price 5 Cents

versity's chemistry research laboratories at 11.30 A. M., it was
learned.
Subsequent to the inspection, a
luncheon will be served in Levering
Hall, at 12.30 P. M. Dr. Ames will
be host to donors and their wives at
a dinner to be given at the Baltimore Country Club, 6 P. M.
To Present Address, Film

The conference will be culminated by an address, "Leadership,"
scheduled to be delivered at 8 P. M.,
by Dr. Arthur D. Little, noted
chemical engineer, in the C. E. Hall,
Room 120. In addition, the sound
picture "Cosmic Rays," a speech
presented at the first conference in
1929 by Dr. Robert A. Millikan,
famous physicist, will be shown.
Only those who have obtained complimentary tickets from the office of
Dr. Neil E. Gordon, Remsen 105,

PASSES PUT TURNBULL
IN SCORING POSITION
Two Lyons To Bauer Forwards
Place Hopkins On 6-Yard
Line
A blocked attempt to score an extra point after touchdown proved
to be the deciding factor in a close
game at Swarthmore and Hopkins
finished on the long end of a 7-6
score last Saturday. Lang, a freshman end, blocked Dellmuth's attempt for the extra point after
Schemb had scored ill the final
quarter.
Against Lehigh, two weeks ago,
the Jays met a team with more experience and were defeated. Against
Rutgers last week the Black and
Blue gridders were outweighed and
the process was repeated. But Saturday the Hopkins team was pitted
against an eleven of ,equal caliber
and the result was a victory by the
margin of a lone point. The victory
was not overwhelming but it was
the result of a hard-fought, bitterly
contested battle.
First Period Scoreless

With two equally strong teams
trying each other out the first period
was scoreless. Each team made
gains but neither was able to cross
the other's goal line. Swarthmore
had an opportunity to score late in
this period when Schemb punted to
Lyons and the latter fumbled.
Keefer, Garnet guard, recovered the
ball in Hopkins' territory and the
Pennsylvanians were in a position
to score. However,- a stubborn Jay
line held for three downs and then
Dellmuth attempted a field goal. As
a forewarning of what was to come,
lang blocked the placement kick and
the quarter ended before the home
team was again in-. a scoring position.
Passes Advanced Hopkins

With the beginning of the second
quarter the Jays' attack began to
function. A long pass from Lyons
to Bauer placed the ball deep in the
Garnet territory. --Another long
pass completed by the game two men
left Hopkins in Possession of the
ball on Swarthmore's six-yard line.
Turnbull got four..through the center of the line and on the next play
went across for the 'first score of
the game. Bauer added the extra
point with a placement kick that
went between the crossbars. There
was no more scoring during the
quarter and the half -ended with
Hopkins seven points._ in the lead.
Swarthmore .seemed determined
to at least tie the score in the second
half and all during the third quarter threatened the Jay goal. However, the Black and 'Blue team stiffened whenever danger seemed imminent and the third period passed
without a score.
Lang Blocks Kick

In the middle of the last quarter
Lyons punted while in the shadow
of his goal posts. The ball went to
Schemb on the Hopkins' 40-yard
line. Cutting through the entire Jay
team when it seemed certain that he
would be stopped the:•Garnet fullback back scored. 'It' was then that
Lang again broke up: Delln-iuth's attempted kick and, victory. for the
visitors was assured. . Neither. team
could score during the,remainder of
the contest.

EDITORIALS
CRITICISM
is a power very much abused at johns Hopkins, both
CRITICISM
by the critics and the criticised. The former, finding this enticing
weapon so readily within his grasp, is often carried away by his more
or less venomous attitude and rather than being coldly critical and
constructive be becomqs vulgarly insulting—a condition vividly illustrated in this university in several notorious cases. This unfortunate
tendency, with some exceptions, seems due to a fervent desire to rise
beyond the bounds of the conventional and commonplace to the plane
of originality. It is a laudable craving, no one is more uninteresting
or exasperating than the confirmed, self-satisfied Victorian. Yet
original criticism must also be intelligent and not have to include disparagement and insult to command the attention. It must be in good
taste and good taste does not look to conventionalism for its limits.
It is only to the conventional and narrowminded themselves that it
ever does o. However, good taste and intelligence to a great extent
do walk hand in hand and if the critic would desire to cater to the
intelligensia he should also cater to this sense of good taste.
The criticised we find are affected by criticisms in two ways. On
the one hand we find smug indifference and on the other garrulous
savageness. In truth, both are but different attitudes occasioned by
the same fundamental fault; that is, utter disregard of any intelligent
opinions which the critic may, with a serious desire at improvement,
have advanced. This fault may not be so clear in the overferocious
as in the indifferent. The former seldom considers the critic's arguments as an attempt at helpfulness, which sometimes it is, but rather
as a vengeful assault upon his personal honor. He enters the fray
much in the same attitude as the aforementioned critic and childish
epistles fly back and forth in puerile enmity. It is a question which is
the worse evil. In neither case is the critic given the answer which
the merits of his observations deserve.
THE NEWS-LETTER is the only organ of University opinion and,
as such, it is its policy to print whatever matter it can of this kind that
is responsibly submitted to it. It seems that in an intellectual institution like the Johns Hopkins University intelligent criticisms should
appear, be accepted and answered as such, no matter to what member
or department of the institution, student, faculty, or administrative it
may be addressed. We hope that in the future we will receive just
criticisms and that these criticisms be given the importance they
deserve.

BIOLOGY I
on the subject of criticisms we are reminded of one that
WHILE
has oftentimes been brought, usually humorously, however, to
our attention. That is, the untrustworthiness of the college catalogues.
We would like to point to a specific case.
Three lecture classes and two laboratory periods have been prescribed as the required hours for Biology I. However, upon enquiring
from several students we find that the biology department assigns so
much laboratory work that it is impossible for the students to complete
the material unless the equivalent of at least three afternoons are spent
in the laboratory each week. This procedure is not only unfair to the
students, who receive no credit for the compulsory time spent, but
also to the other departments of the University, who must suffer when
the students discover this unforeseen drain on their time. If the biology
department requires more than two afternoons a week in which to
present its course, then official recognition should be made of the fact
and due credit given.

A. F. of L. Backs Capitalists

-In the meanwhile, what is the
organized labor, the A. F. of L.,
doing to alleviate this condition of
unemployment that is so evident?"
Mr. Gitlow explained that it could
do nothing. "As long as industry
is run for profit, and not to supply
the needs of man, suffering will
occur." He showed that the only
solution to the problem was either
to supply work to the laborers, or to
protect them by social insurance of
some kind. The former alternative
is evidently impossible under the
capitalistic system and the A. F. of
L. has shown itself to be definitely
opposed to insurance, backing the
stand of the capitalists.
"The crying need of the worker,"
he concluded is an effective realistic
labor union with a gvo4-1 program,
and a rank and file to fight for it.
An enlightening discussion followed the address, in which Mr.
Gitlow answered questions on the
salient points of Communist policy.

on the "Yellow Dog Contracts."
